post_text: Possibly no one would remember James M. Taft as a preacher, instead they would remember him as a teacher, principal, school administrator, charcoal industry developer and the "father of Fall Creek Falls State Park". He built the first county owned high school in Van Buren County and served as it's principal. This was after the closure of Burritt College. Until that time the county had contracted with the college to operate the high school. If you enjoy a visit to Fall Creek Falls this is the man you have to thank! Everyone in Van Buren County knew him as "Peckerwood".

post_text: On the left is the historical marker the state issued. At the right is probably how it should read. The state marker suggest that a local blacksmith Elihu Burritt founded the college. Elihu Burritt was a peace leader and the founder's named the college after him. There is no indication Elihu Burritt ever trod a step in Spencer. Reminder the Burritt College Reunion is Sat Sept 14th. Hope to see you there.

post_text:
This the senior picture of J.K. Stanley. He was very athletic at Burritt. He taught for several years in Van Buren then moved to Warren County where he was principal of Irving College High School. He wrote the Burritt Alma Mater.
"By old Spencer's eastern border.
Reared against the sky.
Proudly stands our Alma Mater.
As the years go by.
Forward! Ever be our watch word.
Conquer and prevail!
Hail to thee! Our Alma Mater!
Burritt hail! All hail!'

post_text: In addition to serving as an institution for education, a Confederate military headquarters, a federal military headquarters, a county government building, and sundry other purposes, a Burritt College administration building has also served as a medical/nursing facility. In 1920 the present administration building was, indeed, converted to a hospital for a brief time. Please see the attached excerpt from the autobiography of Erin Cook Horton.

post_text: Thanks to Donovan Rhinehart for sending this photo of his grandmother Daisy Cook. She is in the window at Burritt College on Thanksgiving day 1922. She was 18 at the time. After Burritt College she married and had two fine sons. She was a beloved teacher in Van Buren County and touched the lives of many. Everyone remembers or has heard of "Miss Daisy"!

post_text: It's 1939, Burritt College had closed. The tiny town of Spencer saw it's mayor and aldermen lose interest as the city was in the "red". So before women's liberation the women of the town step up and take control. They run for office and in this photo from a meeting of town government you will see Osma Lewis, Belle Bouldin, Mayor Cora Gordon, Police Chief Laura Cook and the remaining aldermen Lonnie, Graham, Myrtle Rasco and Lector Page. Yes! they attended or had connections to Burritt College.

post_text: This is what is remaining of the Burritt College building today. Until a few weeks ago the county administrative offices were housed here. The third floor was removed in the 1960's. The Burritt museum building is close to this building. The museum is open Fri and Sat from 10AM-3PM.

post_text: The 71st Burritt College reunion was held Sept 8th at the college in Spencer. Enjoyed hearing the stories and seeing the pictures of the men and women who went forth to become some of the leading citizens of our state and nation. The historical marker is wrong. If you will read to the right of it you will see the true beginning of Burritt.

post_text: I have wondered where the original Burritt administration building and associated dormitories stood with respect to the present building. The picture made soon after the 1906 fire appears to show a dormitory in the background in the left edge of the frontal photo. The 1926 photo shows a dormitory in the background (behind the one in the foreground). Is this one of the original dormitories? Did the original administration building stand behind the position of the present building -and shifted slightly northward? I understand that the original administration building was not torn down until after 1890. Does anyone out there have answers?

Did the original administration building stand behind the position of the present building -and shifted slightly northward? I understand that the original administration building was not torn down until after 1890. Does anyone out there have answers?

post_text:
Why are annuals so important? Hidden in each annuals are pictures of the background of the town of Spencer. Like Streets and buildings. It is the only known evidence of the impact of the 1906 fire and the 1906 "Cyclone". The printing company did not keep copies. The Liveley Studies did not keep copies of the photos
either. All students records were send to Lipscomb when the school closed.
text:
Why are annuals so important? Hidden in each annuals are pictures of the background of the town of Spencer. Like Streets and buildings. It is the only known evidence of the impact of the 1906 fire and the 1906 "Cyclone". The printing company did not keep copies. The Liveley Studies did not keep copies of the photos
either. All students records were send to Lipscomb when the school closed.

post_text:
ALMA MATER
On old Spencer's Eastern border
Reared against the sky
Proudly stands our Alma Mater,
As the years go by.
Forward ever be our watchword, conquer and prevail.
Hail to thee our Alma Mater - Burritt Prep, All Hail!

post_text: Burritt College was founded in 1848 at Spencer, Van Buren County, Tennessee as a preparatory school and junior college under the auspices of the churches of Christ. The college was an early coeducational institution with a classical curriculum along with strict moral and religious codes.
text: Burritt College was founded in 1848 at Spencer, Van Buren County, Tennessee as a preparatory school and junior college under the auspices of the churches of Christ. The college was an early coeducational institution with a classical curriculum along with strict moral and religious codes.
